Bifunctional nano-ZrO2 modification of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode enabling high-energy density lithium ion batteries
Xing Yang a, Yiwei Tang b, Yaohui Qu c, Guozhi Shang a, Jian Wu a, Jiangfeng Zheng b, Yanqing Lai a, Jie Li a, Zhian Zhang a,*
a School of Metallurgy and Environment, Central South University, Changsha, Hunan, 410083, China b Guangdong Jiana Energy Technology Co., Ltd., Qingyuan, 511500, China c School of Physics, Communication and Electronics, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang, Jiangxi, 330022, China
H I G H L I G H T S
� Ni0.92Co0.08(OH)2 precursors are fabricated through precipitation process. � Combination of Li2ZrO3 coating and Zr4þ doping is achieved on LNCO cathode. � LiNi0.92Co0.08O2–Zr2.0% cathode exhibits enhanced cycling and rate capability.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: LiNi0.92Co0⋅08O2 cathode Nano-ZrO2 Li2ZrO3 coating Zr4þ doping Bifunctional modification
A B S T R A C T
Layered LiNiO2 cathode has been considered as an applicable cathode candidate for high energy density and lowcost lithium-ion batteries. However, unsatisfactory cyclability and rate capability impede its large-scale applications. We report here nano-ZrO2 modified LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode, designing to provide an effective and practical strategy for solving the thorny problems. Combination of Li2ZrO3 coating layer with concentration gradient of Zr4þ doping on LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode is achieved through addition of moderate nano-ZrO2 during two-stage sintering process. It is found that the LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% cathode exhibits optimal electrochenmical performance with an initial discharge capacity of 200.3 mAh g 1 at 0.5 C within the voltage window of 2.8–4.3 V and a capacity retention ratio of 82.90% is obtained after 100 cycles. In contrast, LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode delivers a higher initial capacity of 204.4 mAh g 1, but only a capacity of 59.01% is retained. Speciallly, a discharge capacity of 175.7 mAh g 1 (&164.3 mAh g 1) at 5 C (&10 C) rate confirms excellent rate capability of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% cathode. Feasible industrialization of bifunctional modification by nano-ZrO2 provides an effective solution for rapid capacity decay issue of nickel-rich layered oxide cathodes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) based on lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been proved to be an effective way to deal with the energy crisis caused by the tight supply of fossil fuels [1–3]. Limited by unsatisfactory driving mileage, battery cost and short calendar life, the popularization of EVs and HEVs faces with numerous difficulties and obstacles [4,5]. Specially, cathode materials have been identified as restrictive factors for high energy and low-cost LIBs, in which layered LiNiO2 cathode has been considered as an applicable cathode candidate [6,7]. However, many thorny problems impede its large-scale applications. For example, structural disorder caused by
cation mixing of Ni2þ and Liþ will lead to uncontrollable stoichiometric ration, which can accelerate capacity loss during cycling [8,9]. Besides, surface degradation from layered structure to NiO rock salt, accompanying by oxygen gas and heat release, results in poor thermal stability [10,11].
Up to now, many strategies, including elemental doping [12–18], compound coating [19–22] and morphology tailoring [23,24] have been proposed to circumvent the drawbacks. Sun et al. [16] synthesized Zr-doped LiNiO2 cathode through addition of zirconium source during the precipitation process of Ni(OH)2 precursor resulting in improved structural and cycling stability. Manthiram et al. [17] extended calendar life of LiNiO2-based materials by substituting a small-dose of Mg for Li

and Al for Ni in LiNixCo1-xO2 binary cathodes. Therefore, rational elemental doping is an effective way to improve the structural and electrochemical stability of LiNiO2-based materials. Moreover, compound barriers have been considered to effectively avert electrolyte oxidation of the charged cathode. Kalaignan et al. [20] and Xiong et al. [22] designed La2O3 and V2O5 layer on LiNiO2 cathode to reduce the contact area between electrolyte and LiNiO2 cathode, resulting in enhanced structural stability and cycling capability. From the above, it is very necessary to implement the integration of physical cladding and lattice doping for LiNiO2-based materials. In the previous work, Aurbach et al. [25] achieve surface ZrO2 coating by evaporating the mixture of NCM811 cathode, zirconium butoxide in 1-butanol and absolute ethanol solution at 80 �C. Following temperature annealing beyond 700 �C under oxygen atmosphere, a small part of surface zirconium proves to be transferred inside the material. Sun et al. [26], Li et al. [27] and He et al. [28] synthesized Zr-doped precursor through coprecipitation process. Part of the zirconium have been shown to transport from crystal lattice to bulk surface, forming a Li2ZrO3 coating layer during the sintering process. As it turns out, dual functions of Zr-modified LiNO2 and NCM811 exhibited significantly improved capacity retention and thermal stability. Considering the cost and simplicity of dual-functional modification, an economic and practical way is significant to be further explored.
Herein, regular and monodisperse Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors are successful fabricated through precipitation process, and we combine surface Li2ZrO3 coating with Zr4þ doping strategy on LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode through addition of moderate nano-ZrO2 during two-stage sintering process. Existence and composition of surface physical layer are verified by X-ray diffractometer and transmission electron microscopy. Formation temperature of Li2ZrO3 layer as well as design rationality of two-stage sintering process are confirmed by differential scanning calorimeter and thermogravimetric analyzer. Rietveld refinement analysis, elemental mapping and elementary-line scanning of cathode section present concentration gradient of Zr4þ doping in the bulk. The results demonstrate that the LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode with 2.0% (mole percent) ZrO2 addition exhibits optimal structural and cycling stability, rate performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials preparation
sections.text:
Spherical Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors were prepared via controlled co-precipitation approach in continuous stirred-tank reactor (CSTR) with 20 L volume. Firstly, a polymetallic solution was formed by dissolving NiSO4⋅6H2O, CoSO4⋅7H2O in deionized water with a molecular ratio of 92: 8 (Ni: Co). Secondly, a NaOH solution and a NH3⋅H2O solution together with the polymetallic solution were separately fed into a CSTR with the temperature of 55 �C. The pH and stirring speed were monitored throughout the whole process. Finally, the obtained precursors were washed by NaOH solution and warm water, and then filtered and dried at 100 �C for 24 h. The LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode were prepared by sintering mixture of Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors and LiOH⋅H2O in a Li/TM molar ratio of 1.05 at 500 �C for 4 h and heated to 700 �C for 16 h.
To fabricated the ZrO2 modified LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 materials, three different doses with 1.0%, 2.0%, 3.0% (molar weight) of nano-ZrO2 were separately mixed with Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors and LiOH⋅H2O before sintering process. 1.0%, 2.0%, 3.0% (molar weight) ZrO2 modified LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 materials are labeled as LNCO-Zr1.0%, LNCOZr2.0%, LNCO-Zr3.0% cathodes in this paper.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material characterization
sections.text:
X-ray diffractometer (XRD) is employed within the 2θ scope from 10� to 80� at a sweep speed of 2� min 1. Rietveld refinement analysis are
utilized based on the platform of GSAS/EXPGUI program. The morphological characterization of the materials is analyzed using Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, NovaNanoSEM 230) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 20ST). Cross sections for SEM studies are carried out by Argon-ion polishing cutter of Gatan685. The size distribution of precursors is tested by Mastersizer 3000. The state of relative elements is carried out by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. Thermogravimetric Analyzer & Differential Scanning calorimeter (TGA&DSC) curves are obtained by Mettler Toledo.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical measurement
sections.text: A slurry is fabricated by dispersing mixture consisted of cathode, carbon black and PVDF with 8:1:1 by weight in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), and then mixed uniformly within a high-speed conditioning mixer (AR 100, Thinky Corp; Tokyo, Japan). After coating the slurry on aluminum foil and placed it in 80 �C in a vacuum atmosphere overnight, electrode is prepared. The electrochemical properties are measured by adopting 2025 coin-type cells, in which cathode electrode with areal density of 60 g m 2 as working electrode, a lithium metal sheet as counter electrode, Celgard 2400 as the separator, 1.2 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)-ethylmethyl carbonate (EMC) (3:7 in volume) with 2.0% (mass percent) vinylene carbonate (VC) as the electrolyte. Fresh coin cells are assembled in dry Ar-filled glove box. Galvanostatic charge-discharge tests are measured using a LAND CT2001A batterytesting instrument. Coin cells are tested at 27 �C.

sections.heading: 3.1. Materials characterization
sections.text:
The chemical composition of synthesized precursors is consistent with the experimental design from the ICP result (Table S1). The morphology of synthesized Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors is shown in Fig. S1, demonstrating that precursors have spherical morphology and many nano-flaky primary particle regularly stacked into blocks and embedded in the precursor. Particle size and tap densities of Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors are about 9.01 μm (Fig. S2) and 2.04 g cm 3 (Table S1). After sintering mixture of Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors, LiOH⋅H2O with three different quantities of nano-ZrO2, the as-prepared materials exhibit incremental particle size and tap densities. It is noteworthy that the LNCO cathode is close to the chemical formula of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2. In contrast, the lithium composition of nano-ZrO2 modified LNCO has a slight increase, and the Ni composition decreases as the dose of nano-ZrO2 increases, while the Co composition keeps relatively constant. The ICP results imply that Zr4þ tend to substitute Ni2þ/Ni3þ location in the preparation process, which is consistent the previous report [26,29]. SEM image of as-prepared LNCO, LNCO-Zr1% LNCO-Zr2%, LNCO-Zr3% cathodes show in Fig. 1. All of the four cathodes inherit the feature of Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors, in which stacked nano-flaky primary particles turn into compact primary particles after sintering. So all the four cathodes are composed of compact primary particles and maintain the spherical structure. Besides, it is found from the high magnification SEM images of LNCO (Fig. 1b), LNCO-Zr1% (Fig. 1d), LNCO-Zr2% (Fig. 1f), LNCO-Zr3% cathodes (Fig. 1h) that the primary particles of the cathodes become blurred gradually as the amount of nano-ZrO2 modification increases, indicating unknown compound covers the primary particles. It is a remarkable fact that incorporation of nano-ZrO2 during sintering does not affect the overall shape of modified materials.
In order to further verify the unknown compound on the surface of modified cathodes and investigate the crystalline structure of the assynthesized cathodes, the X-ray diffractometer (XRD) is employed. As shown in Fig. 2a, all characteristic peaks of four cathodes bring into correspondence with typical structure of α-NaFeO2 (space group: R-3m),
X. Yang et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226978
in which distinct separations of (006)/(102) and (108)/(110) peaks indicate that all of the materials have well-ordered layered structure [30,31]. It’s worth noting that some impurity peaks can be found in LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes. In order to identify the type of impurity, LiOH⋅H2O and nano-ZrO2 mixture, which are sintered with the same heating treatment condition of cathode, are tested
by XRD. As shown in Fig. 2b, the XRD pattern of the as-obtained material is in keeping with the characteristic XRD patterns of Li2ZrO3 compound (JCPDS: 33–0843). The characteristic peaks of the Li2ZrO3 compound are in accord with the impurity peaks of LNCO-Zr2% and the XRD patterns of nano-ZrO2 cannot be observed in LNCO-Zr2% cathode, demonstrating the existence of Li2ZrO3 in LNCO-Zr2% cathode during the
X. Yang et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226978
synthetic process. Besides, as shown in Fig. 2c–d, both of (003) and (104) plane have slight deviation to the left as the amount of nano-ZrO2 modification increases, suggesting that the unit volume is enlarged by modification. The phenomenon suggests the transportation of Zr4þ from cathode surface to internal crystal framework, and the ion radius of Zr4þ (0.72 Å) which is larger than that of Ni2þ/Ni3þ (0.69/0.56 Å) enlarge unit cell [26–28]. Meanwhile, Rietveld refinement is carried out to examine the crystal structure of samples. Well coincidence between the fitted curves and original curves (Fig. S3) as well as minor values of Rwp and Rp proves the reliable results of the Rietveld refinements. Structural parameters of LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes derived from X-ray Rietveld Refinement are shown in Table 1. The lattice parameters along the c-axis and a(b)-axis are enlarged by incorporation of nano-ZrO2, which identify with the phenomenon of (003) and (104) peak shift. Moreover, the I (003)/I (104) of LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes are 1.464, 1.547, 1.212 and 1.201, respectively, demonstrating that the Liþ/Ni2þmixing decreases with 1% ZrO2 modification and then increases with incremental ZrO2 modification. It is worth pointing out that the results are accord with the cation occupancy of Ni in Li derived from X-ray Rietveld Refinement. This phenomenon should be attributed to a dynamic equilibrium. On the one hand, insertion of Zr4þ hinders the transportation of Ni2þ from transition metal location to lithium layers. On the other hand, the high valence incorporation of Mnþ (W6þ, Zr4þ, Mo6þ, V5þ, Ti4þ) would lead to reduction of Ni3þ to Ni2þ owing to charge conservation within a material [32,33]. Therefore, it is concluded that 1% nano-ZrO2 modified LNCO cathodes is dominant by the first case and the second case become the leading role in the LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes.
The existence of Li2ZrO3 on surfaces and migration of Zr4þ ion from surface to interior materials are further identified by TEM, elemental mapping and elementary-line scanning. As shown in Fig. 3, an obvious Li2ZrO3 coating layer with thickness of 4.953 nm can be observed in LNCO-Zr2% cathode, and interplanar crystal spacing of (104) plane (2.065 nm), which is close to the Li2ZrO3 coating layer, is larger than of LNCO cathode (2.036 nm). Fig. S4 displays the external element distribution of LNCO-Zr2% cathode, in which the mapping images of Ni, Co, Zr are overlapped. It turns out that the nano-ZrO2 is evenly distributed around the precursor resulting in uniform distribution of zirconium on LNCO-Zr2% cathode during sintering process. LNCO-Zr2% cathode section obtained by argon-ion polishing is tested by elemental mapping and elementary-line scanning to analyze interior element distribution. As shown in Fig. 4a-d, the Ni, Co are well distributed in the section, while the Zr element mainly centers around the edge and a part of it diffuse into the material. It can be seen from elementary-line scanning of section (Fig. 4f) that a concentration gradient of zirconium, which decreases gradually from the outside to the inside, is formed. Moreover, TGA&DSC measurement is carried out to further investigate the formation of Li2ZrO3 coating and Zr4þ doping. As shown in Fig. S5a, 14.72% of weight loss of LiOH⋅H2O & Nano-ZrO2 mixture is identified as evaporation of water and crystallized water from materials and LiOH⋅H2O. 10.61% and 3.78% of weight loss can be interpreted as decomposition of segmental Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursor to Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08O2. 3.78% of weight loss should be assigned to complete Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2
decomposition, thermal decomposition of partial LiOH to Li2O, as well as partial reaction between Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 and Li2O. It is worth pointing out that slight weight increment occurs after 500 �C, which should be ascribed to complete LiOH decomposition and further formation reaction of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode. Similar TGA&DSC curves of LiOH⋅H2O & Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 mixture and LiOH⋅H2O & Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 & Nano-ZrO2 suggest that Nano-ZrO2 modification has limited effect on the formation of materials. An apparent exothermic peak around ~430 �C only can be detected in TGA&DSC curves of LiOH⋅H2O & Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 & Nano-ZrO2 mixture and LiOH⋅H2O & Nano-ZrO2 mixture. That means the Li2ZrO3 was formed below 500 �C and Zr4þ transportation mainly occurs in the second sintering section. Surface valence states and composition of elements are investigated
by XPS analysis (Fig. 5). The Ni 2p3/2 peak of Ni XPS spectra displays two separated peaks located at 855.64 eV and 854.54 eV (Fig. 5b), which are assigned to Ni3þ and Ni2þ [34,35]. Larger area of Ni2þ peak in LNCO-Zr2.0% cathode compared to that of LNCO cathode demonstrates higher Liþ/Ni2þ mixing on the LNCO-Zr2.0% cathode surface, which is consistent with the result of XRD analysis. The Co XPS spectra (Fig. 5c) of LNCO cathode and LNCO-Zr2.0% cathode show typical peaks at binding energies of 779.53 eV and 794.34 eV belonging to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, separately, suggesting the Co possesses a valence state of þ3 [36,37]. Otherwise,a main peak of Zr 3d5/2 appeared at 180.98 eV, together with a Zr 3d3/2 peak observed at 183.34 eV in the Zr XPS spectra (Fig. 5d) indicate that Zr has a valence state of þ4 [27,38–40].

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
Initial charge/discharge curves of LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes under the current density of 0.2 C (1 C ¼ 200 mA g 1) in the voltage cutoff of 4.3 V are displayed in Fig. 6a. All the four cathodes display similar curves, implying that presence of nano-ZrO2 modification have a limited effect on Liþ insertion/extraction. The LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes display initial discharge capacities of 211.9, 209.8, 207.2 and 206.6 mAh g 1, and corresponding coulombic efficiencies are 88.18, 85.83, 84.74 and 85.12%, respectively. Lower initial specific capacities and coulombic efficiencies of modified cathodes should be ascribed to the higher Liþ/Ni2þ mixing of nano-ZrO2 modified LNCO cathodes. Cyclic

voltammogram (Fig. 6b) of LNCO cathode is tested in the voltage range of 2.8–4.3 V to further understand the chemical transformation of the LNCO cathode. Three redox peaks represent phase transitions from H1 to M, M to H2 and H2 to H3. M and H is hexagonal phase and monoclinic phase, respectively [41–43]. It is noticeable that phase transitions from
H1 to M, M to H2 cannot be particularly distinguishable in the initial anodic peak, which could be attributed to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) as well as structural adjustment on the surface [43,44].
The cycling performance of LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and
X. Yang et al.
Journal of Power Sources 438 (2019) 226978
LNCO-Zr3% cathodes in the final voltage of 4.3 V is tested at the current density of 0.5 C. As shown in Fig. 6c, the LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes display initial discharge capacities of 204.4, 202.1, 200.3 and 199.9 mAh g 1, and corresponding coulombic efficiencies are 83.38, 81.66, 79.26 and 79.81%, respectively. The LNCO cathode faces tremendous capacity decay after 100 cycles and only a reversible capacity of 120.8 mAh g 1 can be obtained. By contrast, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes show reversible capacities of 142.3, 166.8 and 159.9 mAh g 1 after 100 cycles. The rate performance of four cathodes at different densities within the voltage window of 2.8–4.3 V is shown in Fig. 6d. All cells are tested under the Crates of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 5, 10 C for five cycles, respectively, and the current density recovers to 0.2 C in the last five cycles. The LNCO cathode shows reversible capacities of 201.3, 182.8, 167.9, 152.9, 141.1, 127.0, 104.6 mAh g 1 under the corresponding rates, and the capacity recover to 169.3 mAh g 1 when the C-rate is returned to 0.2 C. In contrast, the modified cathodes display enhanced rate performance, among which the LNCO-Zr2.0% cathode shows optimal reversible capacities of 207.2, 199.4, 192.8, 187.3, 181.8, 175.7, 164.3 mAh g 1
under the corresponding rates and the capacity recovers to 199.3 mAh g 1 when the C-rate is returned to 0.2 C. The excellent rate capability of Zr-doped sample should be attributable to the Li2ZrO3 physical layer with excellent ion transportation characteristics [38,45,46] and enlarged unit volume by Zr4þ doping [47].
In order to get better acquainted with the enhanced electrochenmical performance of nano-ZrO2 modified cathodes, the electrode morphology after cycling, median voltage & dQ/dV curves, as well as
electrochemical impedance spectroscopy are analyzed. As shown in Fig. 7, the LNCO-Zr2% electrode maintains relatively intact morphology, while the LNCO cathode electrode faces a structural failure after 100 cycling at 0.5 C. As previously reported [48–50], secondary particle breakage for the Ni-rich cathodes should be derived from non-directional volume change and subsequent disjunction between primary particles in the material, as well as multiple phase transformations from layered structure to NiO rock salt on the primary particle surface. Therefore, it further demonstrates that secondary particle breakage is suppressed, to a certain extent, by dual function of nano-ZrO2 modification. Fig. 8a exhibits the median voltage curves of LNCO, LNCO-Zr1%, LNCO-Zr2% and LNCO-Zr3% cathodes. The initial median voltages of ZrO2-modified cathodes are higher than that of LNCO cathode, and the trend of the median voltage curves are consistent with that of the cycling curves, which can be explained by dQ/dV curves. As can be seen from dQ/dV curves in Fig. 8b-c, the dQ/dV curves of LNCO cathode and LNCO-Zr2% cathode show similar three cathodic peaks in the first cycle, which is consistent with the results of CV curves. The LNCO-Zr2% cathode shows stable dQ/dV curves from initial cycle to 100 cycle, while the redox peaks of H3 to H2 in dQ/dV curves of LNCO cathode have an apparent left-side shift resulting in median voltages decline. This phenomenon originates mainly from rapid internal impedance increase on account of structural degradation and occurrence of side reactions between the bulk and electrolyte during cycling. Moreover, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the LNCO and LNCO-Zr2.0% cathodes before and after cycling are measured and further fitted by equivalent circuit (Fig. 8g). As shown in Fig. 8d–e, all of

the EIS curves consist of two semicircles and a sloping line, which is connected with the resistance of the surface SEI (solid electrolyte interface) film, charge transfer resistance and the warburg impedance [33,51–53]. The resistance parameters (Table 2) acquired from fitted equivalent circuit show that the Rf (the resistance of the surface SEI film) and Rct (charge transfer resistance) values of LNCO-Zr2.0% cathode are 2.102 Ω, 3.907 Ω in the initial cycle, which is lower than that of the LNCO cathode. After 100 cycles, the Rf and Rct values of LNCO-Zr2.0% cathode are also much less than that of the LNCO cathode. It indicates that the kinetic behaviour of Liþ during insertion/extraction process is improved by nano-ZrO2 modification. Furthermore, the lithium ion diffusion coefficients were calculated using Equation (1) [46,54,55] as following:
DðLiþÞ ¼ R2T2

Here, R, T and F represent the gas constant, temperature and faraday constant, respectively; A represents reaction area of electrode (1.5386 cm2 in this report), n is the quantity of electrons participated in reaction; σ is the Warburg coefficient, which is the slope of Z0-ω 1/2 lines in Fig. 8f. C is the concentration of lithium ion in cathode material, which can be calculated according to Equation (2) as following:
C¼ x n V ¼ x ρV=M V ¼ x ρ M

Here, x is the percent of inserted Liþ in the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V; ρ is the actual density; M is the molar mass of cathode materials.
According to Equation (1) and Equation (2), the D (Liþ) of LNCO and LNCO-Zr2% cathodes in the first cycle and after 100 cycles are calculated
and show in Table 2. The LNCO cathode shows D (Liþ) of 1.41 � 10 11 and 2.91 � 10 12 in the first cycle and after 100 cycles, while the LNCOZr2% cathode exhibit improved D (Liþ) of 1.49 � 10 11 and 4.46 � 10 12 under the same conditions. The result demonstrates that LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode with ZrO2 modification enhances the diffusion rate of Liþ, resulting in better rate capability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, regular and monodisperse Ni0⋅92Co0⋅08(OH)2 precursors with particle size of 9.01 μm are successful fabricated through precipitation process. A strategy combined surface Li2ZrO3 coating with concentration gradient Zr4þ doping on LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode is achieved through addition of moderate nano-ZrO2 during two-stage sintering process. Li2ZrO3 layer proves to be formed in the first stage of sintering process and concentration gradient Zr4þ doping in the bulk mainly occurs during the second sintering section. The higher Liþ/Ni2þ mixing lower the initial charge and discharge capacity of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% and LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr3.0% cathode, but it does not affect the cycle performance and the rate performance of the material. In particular, the LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% cathode exhibits optimal electrochenmical performance with an initial discharge capacity of 200.3 mAh g 1 at 0.5 C within the voltage window of 2.8–4.3 V and a capacity retention ratio of 82.90% is obtained after 100 cycles. A discharge capacity of 175.7 mAh g 1 (&164.3 mAh g 1) at 5 C (&10 C) rate confirms excellent rate capability of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% cathode. Feasible industrialization of bifunctional modification by nanoZrO2 provides an effective solution for rapid capacity decay issue of nickel-rich layered oxide cathodes.

metadata.abstractText: Layered LiNiO2 cathode has been considered as an applicable cathode candidate for high energy density and lowcost lithium-ion batteries. However, unsatisfactory cyclability and rate capability impede its large-scale applications. We report here nano-ZrO2 modified LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode, designing to provide an effective and practical strategy for solving the thorny problems. Combination of Li2ZrO3 coating layer with concentration gradient of Zr4þ doping on LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode is achieved through addition of moderate nano-ZrO2 during two-stage sintering process. It is found that the LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% cathode exhibits optimal electrochenmical performance with an initial discharge capacity of 200.3 mAh g 1 at 0.5 C within the voltage window of 2.8–4.3 V and a capacity retention ratio of 82.90% is obtained after 100 cycles. In contrast, LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2 cathode delivers a higher initial capacity of 204.4 mAh g 1, but only a capacity of 59.01% is retained. Speciallly, a discharge capacity of 175.7 mAh g 1 (&164.3 mAh g 1) at 5 C (&10 C) rate confirms excellent rate capability of LiNi0⋅92Co0⋅08O2–Zr2.0% cathode. Feasible industrialization of bifunctional modification by nano-ZrO2 provides an effective solution for rapid capacity decay issue of nickel-rich layered oxide cathodes.
